question: What is the Geohacking?
answer: Geohacking is a colloquialism that refers to the practice of altering the environment of an already habitable planet. Geohacking is different from terraforming in that it is done upon planets and moons that already have established atmospheres and environments. It can also refer to modifications done on a smaller scale, and primarily to alter a world’s weather system. The Xi’an Empire utilizes the planets of the Th.us’ūng system for its ongoing research into geohacking and terraforming technologies.

question: What is the Third Imperial Age?
answer: The Third Imperial Age, ruled by House Kr.ē, is the Xi’an Empire’s (SaoXy'an) current dynasty. It began in II.1824 (SEY 1457) with the selection of U.e’o se Kr.ē as the new Emperor, roughly a century after the Kr’thak’s assassination of House Xy.ō. During this era, the Xi’an formally ended hostilities with the Kr’thak, made first contact with Banu, Vanduul, and Humans, and established diplomatic relationships and opened channels of trade with Banu and Humans. The current Emperor, T.uēng se Kr.ē, was one of the signatories of the Akari-Kr.ē Treaty (III.1040 / SEY 2789), the first nonaggression pact between Humans and Xi’an, an instrumental step in the eventual end of the Xi’an-Human Cold War (III.838 - III.1044 / SEY 2530 - 2793). Because he has no heirs, the Third Imperial Age will end upon his death or abdication, and the Fourth Imperial Age will begin with the selection of a new Imperial House.

question: What are the plans for culling in PES?
answer:
Paul: Okay, that's a good question. With our old system, we had this, it's called lifetime management, and it would arbitrarily remove entities once they hit a certain cap. And we realized that's not really great for play experience. For example, I think at the moment, players can only spawn up to three ships. If they spawn another ship, the old one gets removed. For persistent entity streaming, we actually revisit that problem. And we decided, okay, how can we make this a nicer for the player, but also be how can we make this actually work good for persistent streaming and also for server meshing, where maybe it doesn't make sense if if a player has five ships spawned and they're all separated in open space and streamed out, they don't really cost us performance. So why do we still need to arbitrarily limit that? And for that, we have the guys in Frankfurt developed a new system. It's called density management, and it operates on relative cost of an area. So the idea is that instead of just taking arbitrary numbers on objects, we look at areas and we look at the amount of items in that area. And we only start to remove items the moment the relative cost of that area becomes too high. So as long as you spawn your ships in different locations and they're all spread out, we will never touch them or remove them. However, if like now everyone goes to the same spot and you start spawning ships and spawning ships at the same location, that's when the system will find out, OK, now the performance goes down because our relative cost in that specific area goes too high. And then we will start deleting items, which also follows a certain rule set. So we will delete oldest items first. We will also have a relative priority on items. So a player ship, for example, is a very high priority item. So we would not delete a player ship versus a coffee cup, for example, would be the first item to go away. And then with that, we try to get the game to where it's not very invasive to you. So you don't just see stuff disappearing out of the air. Exactly like the approach we're taking is that most of this cleanup will happen during stream out. So if an area streams out, that's when the density management will make a first initial pass and will say, hey, in this area, we had 50 coffee cups and that's too much. So we start removing them. And then we only go into the more aggressive policies once it's really becoming maybe an area never streams out or whatever. All players decided, hey, I mean, I kind of expect that right once we go get PSL probably everyone will like, let's all go to Port Olisar and drop all our coffee mugs on the floor and keep doing that. That's what you guys will do anyways. So basically the system will take care of this, but it will be a smarter system. It's a smarter system than what we have right now.

Benoît: One thing to add to thedensity management too, is that it also has this concept of references. And so for example, if an entity, because this also covers NPC entities, right? So like AIs and whatever else. And so if a specific entity is actually being referenced by a mission, active mission or active player, for example, then there's a ref counting, a reference counting system that will prevent those from being actively reaped. So that, again, I think the goal with density management is really to make sure stuff doesn't pop out of your view and break your game experience. But we still need a density management system to prevent overloads. But that's the approach in general.
title: Star Citizen Live: Persistent Entity Streaming

question: How far along are physicalized vehicle components?
answer:
The props team has already been working on the models for the vehicle components (you can already see them in some shops), and hundreds of vehicle items have already been made. They are currently making sure that they are all fully release-ready.
Any vehicle released in the last 18 months has already got spaces for all of the vehicle components, and any new ships will be released with spaces for their components. Currently, they are going back through the older ships (such as the Retaliator) to create spaces for the physicalized vehicle components.
At the moment, any component you see inside a ship is not the actual item, but instead just a texture replicating the look of the item. Some ships (such as the Carrack) do have the actual ship components inside the ship. There is currently an issue where the vehicle components are attached to the exterior of the ship (they look like they are placed inside the ship, but they are attached to the exterior), meaning that while the player can see them, they are unable to interact with the components. The vehicle tech team will be working on fixing this issue next quarter, allowing the component to be connected to all the external systems automatically. When this issue is fixed, players will be able to see the component inside their ship visually change when they replace the component.

question: And how do you approach designing these ships? Especially since you are going with a Newtonian physics model in the game. So especially with the really big ones, and having all these smaller ships in the vicinity, and I’m assuming you’ll often have planets or moons or stars in the backdrop… how do you, sort of, design these ships, and balance gameplay around them?
answer:
Sure, yeah. That- the ships are a very exciting pipeline for Star Citizen. It was one of the earliest- we knew we were making spaceships, obviously (laughs). So that was one of the first things we developed and focused a lot of time on. And as time has gone on, we’ve grown a lot better at making them. We’ve gotten the right amount of staff and talent, which is an incredible talent here at Cloud Imperium, that is all focused on making ships not just match the design of that ship and how it fits into our universe, but also we some very invested, very smart, and very talented engineers on our staff, and Chris himself, all of whom understand what it takes to make you feel like you’re flying an actual spaceship. There are very few people in our world who actually know what it feels like to fly a spaceship-
– yeah, maybe a couple hundred!
– Yeah! So we’re working within the boundary of physics. Space physics tend to be easier than atmospheric physics. But we have a couple, we have several developers and engineers that are focusing on how to make this feel like a simulation- how would it feel if I got into my cockpit and flew off this planet, any planet, and enjoyed a space flight? So in the designing aspect, everyone’s involved from start to finish. We’ve figured out what ship and manufacturer makes the most sense, and what kind of ship should go with what manufacturer. You know, like you buy a Mercedes-Benz when you are looking for something, but not a Chevy, they’ll all have different aspects to what they are. We want to do the same with our manufacturers of the future. So we start with the designing idea of that ship, and we have our pipeline set up and established, it’s a very clean pipeline that we are all very proud of. And so it goes to the pipeline- art, tech design, engineering, gameplay implications, the features, systems, how they all interact. And we’ve got IFCS, which is our intelligent flight control system. That is essentially driving- you know, you tell your ship to do something, and then IFCS reacts, as it should in a simulation. We’re always working to refine it, tweak it, make it more realistic but also more fun. So we’re always working on balancing those things to make it feel like what we’d like it to feel like.
title: Star Citizen Interview – A Game As Infinite As The Universe Itself

question: Hi Erin, thanks for taking the time to chat to us. I wanted to start with something that is perhaps slightly peripheral to the game itself and discuss Brexit. Obviously we had a couple of emails last year about the topic in advance of the vote and there was mention of a possible risk to the UK videogame tax breaks. Given that we now know the outcome and the UK will be leaving the EU, is there any immediate impact to you guys?
answer:
Erin Roberts: As a company, we’d probably rather that the UK didn’t exit the European Union as a lot of our staff are from all over the EU, we’ve got some great people here and there is uncertainty as well as potentially making it harder for us to hire the people we want.

That much said, in terms of the immediate impact to the company, it’s actually been somewhat surprisingly positive because of the change in exchange rates and the fact that we as a company do the majority of our development in the UK, but of course the majority of our revenue is in US dollars, it actually meant that given the Sterling crash, UK development has effectively become cheaper.

Additional to that is the tax credits situation from the UK government, that law is likely to change due to the way it was implemented as a European-wide law, but right now at least the UK government is promising that will stay intact.

So short to medium term looks ok, obviously we have a 2 year period while the UK negotiates its exit from the EU, longer term is of course still unpredictable until we get the detail on how the exit works. Close to perhaps 25% of our staff are from the EU and given that we support a global community, the language skills they come with are also very beneficial to us.
title: The Star Citizen Exclusive Interview: Erin Roberts

question: What do you do on a day to day basis to help keep things moving within CIG and what are your responsibilities as Global Head of Production?
answer: [Special Episode with answers from Erin Roberts]So there's a couple of things I do because there's one is. Obviously as you say i'm Global Head of Production so that involves a lot more travel in terms of going around the different offices coordinating with the different production faults and making sure we have our plans for what we're delivering and the different masters not only for Squadron 42 but also on the Persistent Universe there's a lot of planning and we're just making sure we have the right resources in the right places and the right, the ownership of which studios and so forth. So there's a lot of that level of things.But also I directly run the UK office and so there's a lot of stuff I do on that side and also when i'm travelling i'm very fortunate to have some very good support staff in the office which keep things moving while i'm away. So there's basically two levels there's one that's a much more global level and there's also just the, much of a micro level on the office level in the UK. So that's basically the two different responsibilities that I juggle a lot. As well as the Frankfurt office is actually part of Foundry 42 and although that's managed by Brian, who does an awesome job over there as well, I have some responsibilities for that side as well.
title: 10 for the Chairman: Episode 80

question: This question concerns mostly Squadron 42, but, in some extent, may also concern Star Citizen: can we expect dogfights inside huge structures (like space stations) where the piloting skills will be the only things that will keep you alive (basically, like in Star Wars, when they fly into the Deathstar)?
answer: So that is a good question and I, that is absolutely a goal for, there will be gameplay that will give you that kind of close in dogfighting skills. So in Squadron 42. The Shubin Mining Station is about six kilometres long and there's lots of structure stuff on it and so part of our plans is to have some low flying combat that's happening there. So if you're going after an OMC Outlaw you'd have to go close to it and plan and fire and so have that flying close to the structure. There's other plans to have similar things like in asteroid fields and i'm pretty sure we will also work in that kind of stuff in some cases in the persistent universe 'cause it's just really cool game play and it rewards good piloting skills.The issue with it is mostly is just getting the AI to fly smart enough. They go close and they just whack into it and it just defeats the whole purpose. I think there was one time the asteroids in Vanduul Swarm weren't really on the radar of the AI and so you could just get all the Vanduul to basically ram into asteroids and kill themselves. So the AI's really the hold-up and AI is a big thing for us. It's a big focus right now for the project because there's a lot of AI dependencies in Squadron 42 that we need to finalise up but we want to roll out more AI into the persistent universe.So in Crusader we have some basic space flight stuff but we also want to have folks on the various space stations going about their daily lives and a higher degree of that and also have some AI on FPS combat and stuff like that. Encounters that you could maybe go to a location and maybe clear out some outlaws or something like that. So all those are being worked on and we definitely will have some close flying structures.
title: 10 for the Chairman: Episode 75

question: How has your writing focus for Star Citizen changed from the start of the project until now, and how do you see it changing in the future? When it comes to making missions or things to do in the PU, do you create the stories for them first or do they get built based on gameplay requirements?
answer: Will Weissbaum: Well, we'll start with the first part. How do you feel writing has changed since we have begun this crazy journey called Star Citizen?Dave Haddock: It's certainly become much more interesting because it's-... now that we're having things come online - conversation systems and actual mechanics and stuff like that - you get more of a direct plug-in of like, you need to write something for this, that needs to accommodate for this system. Rather than before, where it was-... for the early news updates we were trying to write about what the plan was for game design aspects, and now we can actually kind of write about game aspects.WW: The project has definitely gotten to the point now where we're starting to really focus on specific content, and churning out scripts, and getting things done for moving into recording stuff, and really heading into the production phase of things, and moving out from more of our kind of brainstorming and dreaming-of-lore days. So that's kind of fun to see that switch happen - get more focused and lot more panicked... panicked all the time.So the second question - when making missions and things do we create the stories first or do they get based on gameplay requirements?DH: I think at this point we're still building a lot of the mechanics around the PU, so we haven't gotten into specific mission stuff. We're sort of-WW: Tony and the guys have been doing a lot of experimentation with figuring out, like - without story applied on top of it - just how the missions work from getting the player from "here to here". So, we're gonna - once they sort of have a handle on that - we'll be able to dive back in and start building up with stories, and how to tie it into this bartender and going to this system, and you know, what are you carrying that's interesting?DH: And yeah, maybe one the process gets equalized it might be a half-and-half type thing. If we come up with something - because we have a better understanding of how it could be implemented - we could theoretically pitch ideas and they could just pitch stuff back to us and go, "hey we have this new thing - could you do a mission for us?". So it's probably gonna be a bit more even. Right now we're sort of taking cues from them as to how they wanna-, how they see that sort of mechanic working out.WW: Yeah. And we'll come in more, definitely, on those missions that are gonna be designed to kind of twist your expectations or be a spin on the normal everyday missions. That where we'll come in and-... Squadron 42 - even though you didn't ask - with that it's kind of more we start a very high-level story that sets the initial road map down of where we're going narratively, and then the designers take that and plan locations and more specifics of gameplay. And then they pitch that back to us, and we take it and we start saying like, "oh, well that's interesting! If they're gonna be in a fight right before they have this big heartfelt talk then maybe we can adjust the fight. Maybe we can, rather than being a big battle, we make it just a one-on-one fight with this guy cos it'll be more impactful," and Design says, "no, that won't work - how about 3 guys?". So that kind of finding that beautiful middle-ground between gameplay and narrative.
title: 10 for the Writers: Episode 02 (2015.01.05)

question: Are the FPS and Space Battles going to be instanced separately?
answer: If the question is, say, if I'm in a space battle and some players and I board a ship will that be instanced separately then the answer is no. Inside one instance which would include space-ships AND FPS, now we'll have some network optimisations that might separate these scenarios, as we upgrade to AC 2.0 for multicrew ships as well as introducing the FPS module, but they are generally planned to be kept in the same instance.
title: 10 for the Chairman: Episode 44 (2014.11.10)

question: Will there be lore specific things hidden throughout the Persistent Universe? Things that don't necessarily have a monetary value, but will add depth to the galaxy's story and the game itself.Like the discovery of a long lost derelict ship, the cause of the extinction of a civilization, or the source of Xi'an religious traditions, and if so, will these things be unique, meaning only the person who finds it will have it?
answer: That's a great question, we are definitely planning on having lore building, universe building things out there. So derelict ships, alien artifacts, all that kind of stuff.I think in some cases... There will be persistence with this stuff, so there'll be a limited amount of items. Maybe there will only be 1 of one thing, and maybe there'll be 10 of another thing, but there will definitely be these sort of things that we'll pepper around.Essentially, everybody won't have the "Ark of Truth" themselves if you know that I mean. We'll try to make it so there's a certain amount of artifacts and stuff that you can discover and use, and some will be unique, then some will not be one off, but they'll be a one of a set kind of thing. I think it should be pretty cool.We're gonna definitely try and have this sort of stuff for the salvage and the explorer gameplay mechanic down the road.
title: 10 For the Chairman Episode 27. June 30th, 2014

question: Will there be collision in dogfighting? If yes, will the colliding ships sustain damage?
answer: Yes is the simple answer on that. There definitely is collision in the dogfighting and you do sustain damage.In fact, I'm not sure if... Well if we've shown it on some of the videos, but yeah, one of the actual ways that people tend to die is they collide, because the speed of the ships is pretty deceptive. I know I saw a few comments thinking the ships weren't actually flying that fast, but they actually are flying pretty fast.So when you're doing a head to head pass, a lot of times you have to watch it 'cause you're far away, then all this sudden it's right there and you're like "Oh no," and pull up, and if the two people pull up in the same direction, boom.We're gonna tweak that damage, but there's definitely damage that gets sustained in collisions in the dogfighting and in general in space.
title: 10 for the Chairman Episode 19. May 5th, 2014

question: Several Months ago, Chris Roberts made a comment about looking into the possibility of making an official SC gamepad or HOTAS. Is there and further word on if this is going to happen?
answer: Yeah, I mean we ran a poll on having the official Star Citizen controller. Like was there a particular manufacturer you liked, and so that poll was really part of that initiative. So we are moving forward with a long term plan for that. It won't be anything that will happen before the Dogfighting Module, but I think you could see us making some announcements after the Dogfighting Module.Long term we definitely want to do that.We've been talking to the various peripheral manufacturers, and quite a lot of them are keen to do stuff with us about making some sort of Star Citizen themed controllers, and also have say a HOTAS that is specifically configured to work really well with Star Citizen. So you know we map all the keys and all the buttons and the joystick to everything that's happening in the cockpit. That includes being able to have an analogue look around like say on a hat and stuff like that.So we're definitely working on that, and that will be pretty cool.I mean we'd enjoy our official Star Citizen game pads and t-shirts and hoodies, and we'd definitely want our own official joystick and mouse and all that kind of stuff.
title: 10 for the Chairman: Episode 09 (2014.02.24)

question: In the Dogfighting Module, how will you balance ships by class/size? Will there be limits on the number of Hornets? Freelancers? Etc? I can't see a round of dogfighting with 8 Constellations against 8 Hornets being fair :)
answer: Well let's see, I think I would be interested to see eight Constellations against eight Hornets 'cause I'm not so sure it will be quite as one-sided as you think. They both have different pros and cons, so depending on how you're fighting and what you're doing, it may be a closer fight than you think. But we're going to have various categories in the matchmaking. We've been playing with various matchmaking set-ups. One of them is you assign points to ships, so an Aurora would be something like one point, but a Constellation could be five points. Don't quote me on these points because this is just for illustration purposes. Then each team gets to have 30 points or something like that. So you can make the trade off between lots of little ships or a fewer smaller-bigger ships. Then we'll probably also have matchmaking that just Hornet v Hornet or Aurora v Aurora. So we'll have various options that you'll be able to choose from the matchmaking system in the Dogfighting Module.
title: 10 for the Chairman: Episode 03 (2013.12.20)
